_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at your facility:

Risk Management and Safety are important concerns at Johns Manville. The Risk Management Program and Process Safety Program formalize and document these activities. Johns Manville is committed to conducting its operation in a safe, responsible manner and to reducing risks to health and the environment.



A description of your facility and the regulated substance handled:

This facility manufactures polyisocyanurate insulation panels for the construction industry. A flammable mixture containing two related substances, n-pentane and isopentane, is used in the manufacturing process. 



The worst case and alternative release scenarios:

The hypothetical worst-case scenario is a failure of the 30,000-gallon storage tank when filled to capacity, despite a 90% capacity limit, resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. According to hazard modelling software, impacts from this explosion using the worst-case assumptions could cause injuries and damage property located in an area between the storage tank and the hazard endpoint. The hazard endpoint in this case corresponds to an overpressure of 1 pound per square inch (psi) and is estimated to extend 0.4 miles from the storage tank.

The alternative release scenario involves a hose rupture caused by a truck that pulls away while the hose is still connected to the pentane tank. This would result in a spill of approximately 7 gallons (this amount is the maximum quantity of pentane that could be in the hose). If a spark were to ignite the spilled liquid and vapors, the resulting explosion could impact persons or property located within 150 feet of the unloading area. 



The general accidental release prevention program and chemical specific prevention steps:

A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of a pentane release in accordance with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard

and the EPA Risk Management Program. This prevention program provides a structured approach to preventing accidents. Some of the specific activities in the prevention program are described below.



Employee Participation

Employees are encouraged to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention. Employees have access to all information created as part of the accident prevention program. 



Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

An in-depth Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) of the system has been conducted prior to start up and any following risk reduction measures will be implemented. Qualified personnel will revalidate the PHA every five years.



Pre-startup Safety Review and Mechanical Integrity

The Pentane system was designed in accordance with all applicable codes and standards (NFPA, ANSI, ASME, etc.). A Pre-startup safety review will ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and the equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service. This review provides one additional check to make sure that any change is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready. Critical equipment is maintained, tested and inspected on a planned periodic basis to ensure proper operating conditions.



Training

Written operating procedures are used for training and directing the work of operators. To complement the written procedures for process operations, Johns Manville has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process. New employees receive basic training in operations if they are not already familiar with such operations. In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the emergency operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. This refresher training is conducted at least every three years. All of this training is documented fo

r each operator.



Contractors

Johns Manville has procedures in place to ensure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inform personnel of any hazards that they find during their work. Personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations.



Incident Investigation

Johns Manville promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to determine the root causes and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least five years so that the reports can be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA revalidations.



Compliance Audits

To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, Johns Manville periodically conducts an audit to evaluate whether the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented. The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.



The emergency response program:

A written emergency response plan is maintained at

the facility, and our personnel are trained in proper notification and evacuation procedures. In the event of an emergency, the facility will request immediate assistance from the Hillsboro Fire Department.



Planned changes to improve safety:

Safety has been a part of the working culture at Johns Manville. The pentane process is current state of the art and is designed to be as safe as feasibly possible. At this time, no further improvements are planned. Any planned changes will be assessed through the JM Management of Change procedure.
